# Introduction

IDEMS has developed a bespoke RapidPro authoring system which enables partners to support chatbot development by working with content in google sheets and google docs. This system has been used to deploy several RapidPro chatbots over the past 2 years. 

In collaboration with PLH, IDEMS has built a chatbot called ParentText Crisis, which is intended to be used as a starter kit that partners can fork (duplicate) and adapt to their own purposes. IDEMS has recently worked to improve and automate some of the chatbot deployment steps, to the point where third parties can own a significant part of the chatbot authoring process.

This document outlines the steps required for a partner to deploy their own version of ParentText Crisis. While this guidance aims to be as clear as possible, it does contain technical content and language around a range of topics. It is therefore best suited to technical partners who already have some familiarity with RapidPro, GitHub and some general experience in software development.  

## ParentText Crisis Overview

ParentText Crisis has been designed such that it can be used as a starter kit for others to develop their own chatbot. There are a series of spreadsheets that are used in the production of a chatbot, detailed explanation can be found in the [Spreadsheeting System](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1UmSWSdNgfuRZe1WyNBEItGpWnUNd5D49wHkCUAZ3Pzg/edit?tab=t.0#heading=h.ljqkir8qi5x4) section of the [IDEMS RapidPro Authoring Process](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1UmSWSdNgfuRZe1WyNBEItGpWnUNd5D49wHkCUAZ3Pzg/edit?tab=t.0#heading=h.xpkt1jgb8s2o). In the case of ParentText Crisis, the spreadsheets have been organised across different repositories as illustrated in the diagram below.

The templates and content that is consistent across all ParentText crisis deployments is stored in the [template repo](https://github.com/IDEMSInternational/parenttext-templates) and the [crisis base](https://github.com/IDEMSInternational/parenttext-crisis-base) repo. In these repositories, the google sheets used in the chatbot have been downloaded and all stored as plain JSON files. This offers a stable versioning system to ensure that a deployment always refers to the same core content/ templates. To create an actual deployment you need a deployment specific repository, an example of such a repository can be found [here](https://github.com/ParentingForLifelongHealth/parenttext-crisis). This repository contains references to the deployment specific google sheets, as well as a reference to the other parent repos. The reference to other repos follows a hierarchy, so from the deployment repo we refer to the parent that is the crisis base repo.

![][image1]

And then from the crisis base repo we refer to the template repo. 

![][image2]

This means that when we produce a deployment from the deployment repo, all of the necessary content is fetched from the parent, and the templates are fetched from the grandparent.

For someone who is looking to produce a new ParentText deployment, it should not be necessary to modify the template repo or the content base repo, however it is important to understand the overall structure that is used to produce the chatbot. If a crisis deployment deviates significantly from the original version, then it may be necessary to make changes to the referenced repositories, but if required this should be done in collaboration with the IDEMS team.



[image1]: <data:image/png;base64,>

[image2]: <data:image/png;base64,>
